I’ve played it twice—once with three players, and once with four. Maybe this is a fundamental issue with cooperative games, but in this one, I feel that experienced players tend to make the decisions for the group. In Spirit Island, there are Spirits that support or empower others, which allows for more collaboration. Here, you're constantly trying to solve the "puzzle" of the game. Invaders are everywhere, and they explore or build, adding pressure. Primarily, you want to prevent Blight so that the lands don’t collapse. As a group, you identify problems and try to coordinate what actions to take. This happens in several iterations, with different approaches being explored, but ultimately, it’s the more complex Spirits that decide what should be done because, of course, you don’t want to lose the game. You repeat this for several rounds. At times, you feel overwhelmed and the game seems like it’s about to be lost, but eventually, there comes a point when you’ve survived the worst, and you just want to "finish" the game. Often, at that point, nothing exciting happens anymore, and you win the game. Sorry, but I can't recommend it at all.

Erős Pandemic utánérzés, csak nem olyan letisztult.

SZELLEMEK SZIGETE:
A természetvédelmi téma önmagában nagyon érdekes. Egymással kooperálva, ősi szellemekként kell segítenünk egy sziget őslakóinak a betolakodó telepesek építkezéseivel és természetromboló terjeszkedésével szemben. A játékmenet viszont ehhez képest mechanikus, elképesztően monoton, nagyon ismétlődő és végtelenül sokáig tart. Borzasztóan unalmas. Az egymást követő játékfázisok periodikusan ismétlődnek, amíg ki nem tanuljuk az egyedi képességekkel bíró szellemek erősségeit és gyengéit, ehhez azonban legalább 4-5 alkalommal kéne a játékkal játszani, de nem kapcsolódik hozzá izgalmi faktor, tehát az kizárt.
Nem hiszem, hogy játékosként 4x3 órát kéne rászánnom arra, hogy utána majd az 5. játéknál talán majd kialakul a jó élmény. Nevetséges. :-)

Nekem nem sikerült átélni a telepesek ijesztő terjedését, mint előtte sikerült a vírusok terjedését a Pandemic játékban, pedig a két játék között "kísértetiesen" sok a hasonlóság. A Szellemek szigete azonban tényleg csak egy túlbonyolított Pandemic klón, és sokkal jobb az.

A tervezők sokféle variálhatóságot belevittek, mégis egysíkúak a kijátszott lapok adta lehetőségek. Ahogyan az is, hogy milyen döntések mentén tudjuk kordában tartani az egyre intenzívebben terjeszkedő telepeseket.
A legnagyobb hátrány az irreálisan hosszú játékidő. Az ember érzi, hogy ugyanazokat a köröket rója, ugyanaz történik, és sosem lesz vége.

Ha annyira fanatikus gémer lennék, hogy azt gondolnám, nem a játék van értem, hanem én vagyok a játékért, biztosan több időt adnék neki, hogy megszeressem, talán tetszene is a végére, de így csak azt látom, hogy egyáltalán nem eredeti az ötlet, a Pandemic által bevezetett mechanika visszaköszönése pedig kifejezetten zavaró.
A hasonló mechanizmus a Tiltott-sorozat darabjainál még ötletesen tért vissza, ott nem csap pofán az érzés, hogy teljesen ugyanazt kapom már megint, csak más köntösben.

De a fő negatívum, hogy szinte csak úgy lehet megnyerni a játékot, ha a félelem lapok mind elfogynak a félelem pakliból, azok meg nagyon nehezen akarnak sorra kerülni. 2 fővel ez nagyon monoton, és mint említettem, túl hosszú az egész.

Nagyon szerettem volna szeretni a Szellemek Szigetét, de pont az ellenkezője történt. Életem leghosszabb szabályértelmezése, legvontatottabb és leginkább monoton játékmnenete, valamint legrosszabb játékélménye. Kifejezetten elhibázott játéknak tartom.

This was a game that my family was recommended to play by a sales assistant in a games shop, as we explained we are fans of interesting co-op games. To our dismay, after having read the rule book, watched several YouTube tutorials and given it a go, we were able to play the game, but barely. My family is quite accustomed to playing complex games, however this one was on another level. First off, the instruction booklet lacked fundamental information. For example, when told to “populate the island boards with invaders, dahans, and blight, as indicated by the icons in each land” there was no key in the instructions as to what each symbol meant. It was only after the fourth video I watched, that I learnt what each symbol meant. I only happened upon the key when looking at my quick-reference cards of which it was on the back. Furthermore, this game, in my opinion, was complicated for the sake of being complicated. Each new rule, special ability and sub-clause, did not add to the game, it merely added to my confusion and
annoyance. Overall, it is unlikely that we will be trying the game many more times, if again at all, which is unfortunate because we had such high hopes for it.

In that, I felt like things were stacked against you from the get go, you had to do things perfectly and rely on a certain amount of luck (2 of us drew power cards 3+ times that not one option would feasible aid us) in order to succeed. I had the same issue with "Battle for Greyport" when played that. People did not have access, even gated, to enough tools to make it work. If I'm going to play something that PvE, I need to know that I have access to tools or success, even if I don't have them right now.

Additionally, there are a lot of elements to it that aren't intuitive at all, and we sought clarification multiple times via online, which isn't unheard of, but they were for basic elements. My best example is the innate traits. I'm not sure the publisher knows what innate means, but it certainly isn't how they have the game setup, and it was a significant frustration (If I can never get traits to fulfull the needs, then you can't use them, and since it requires power draws to do it, and then cards played, you just don't get access to those.)

I don't really care to go on though as this is just a whisper in the wind compared to everyone's glowing reviews. I just know I've played much better co-op games recently in "Paleo" and "Return to Dark Tower" so I'm more than happy to let this dud go without a second playthrough.

In this game, it means using player abilities to remove enemy tokens from the island you protect, either directly or indirectly by cooperating with friendly tokens and cooperate with your friends. Then to have the game make the very same enemy tokens spawn back into the island, while claiming insultingly; This is fun!! And in the next enemy turn we will spawn even more! No, its not fun. To stay afloat you have to either kill some enemy tokens or upgrade your cards/abilities, so you can get ridd of more enemy tokens in the next turn. That's basically your options. It honestly feels like a job and the joyous part is you survived till the end; its finally Friday and no work tomorrow.

Clearly this is a game for a specific kind of player. That player may be you, but after several games (many more than shown here), I have come to the conclusion that it is not me.

Spirit Island is awash with fiddly little mechanisms and minor powers that, in theory, ramp up over time. But because it is cooperative, and consequently the challenge for any given player and their board is random, it can overwhelm you immediately, far beyond your powers to prevent... or it can leave you with a completely unchallenging experience.

In theory, players can thus work together to balance out the state of things, but in practice, this is often not possible. Mostly every player simply inhabits their own little world, at least until the late game. And often the late game is anticlimactic -- if you're winning generally, then you're REALLY winning late; and if you're losing generally, well... suffice it to say that the outcome can be obvious well before the actual end of the game.

Some of these complaints could probably be applied to many or most cooperative games. But where a game like Pandemic has an elegance to its rules, Spirit Island overcomplicates everything. If you'd like a higher difficulty experience, you don't simply add an extra Epidemic card, for instance, but rather you have to apply five new separate difficulty conditions at various points in the turn sequence, and contend with a new lose condition, and modify the effects of certain cards, and on and on. This game comes straight from the "more is more" design school.

Maybe none of this would matter if the gameplay itself were more enjoyable, but it isn't. You're never really pursuing any grand strategy, but mostly it's very narrow-range, tactical decision-making... and that can be fine, but... the best way I can describe it is, you're like a middle-management grunt at McDonalds. You're putting out fires as they pop up (oh no! we're out of Coke syrup, send someone out to replace it fast! oh no! the bathroom needs cleaning because someone puked before reaching the stall! oh no! the ice cream machine is broken again!), just waiting for your fifteen-minute break, hoping that the shift manager doesn't wander by. Your cards/powers are often quite limited, especially early game (and just as fiddly as anything else), so the grand promise of being a powerful spirit never really seems to come to fruition.

In the end, this game is complicated, but does not seem to me to be all that deep. It's more work than it is fun.

A laborious first game when I was still learning soured me on Spirit Island, but after learning to make concessions, I think it's a better game than I realized. Once you're a bit more familiar, managing the rules and the cards is better. It's still a lot of mental load, but I can see how it can be fun. That being said, it has some issues. Many spirits feel out of tune for solo play. Even the rulebook admits that the game isn't balanced around solo. Asking me to play two handed just to get a better experience is too much. While it seems that most spirits are at least somewhat viable solo, they occasionally lean too much toward support or specialist play to feel totally right. This could probably be rectified with more experience, but I feel that so much of the appeal of the game is the excitement of picking a spirit and exploring their playstyles, like picking your favorite character in a fighting game. Yet some of the ones that look or sound most interesting are just too brain-melting to be fun to play.

The component design is great, though. The way invader minis can be reoriented to track their health is ingenious, and the wood/plastic contrast is thematic (not just the jargon-y connotation where thematic=evocative of the setting, but thematic as in literally reinforcing the game's Themes). And the theme (common usage this time) is one of the coolest I've seen in a long time. Ultimately, though, it feels like Pandemic with a slightly convoluted card play system. I enjoyed it but don't love it.

I still really want to try it with a group, as it seems to thrive on interesting synergies and combos--things you don't get as much of solo. One of the major strengths of its design, according to proponents, is the way it alleviates quarterbacking, but this too is irrelevant to solo play, and the complexity and asymmetry that makes alpha-gaming impractical is also the same thing that makes playing alone such hard work. I think I'd really like to try Horizons of Spirit Island, as the cheaper price and emphasis on more straightforward spirits might make it more appealing for solo play.

I love that the complexity comes more from understanding the game flow and how to play it well, and that there’s so many different difficulty sliders you can adjust to tailor the experience to your liking. I definitely see what people love about it. There’s so much depth and interesting synergies to discover with the card powers and the asymmetry, which probably just gets better with multiple plays. Could see myself rating this higher if I get to play it more.

Also setting it apart from other games with the “players do good thing, game do bad thing” -dynamic is that the bad happenings are, with the exception of the exploration card flip, completely open and calculable information for players. Really makes a big difference to the overall feel of the game since you can appropriately plan for pretty much everything that’ll be happening two rounds before it does. Makes for some really crunchy decision space with how to use the powers and how they interact together, especially since depending on the power it can either trigger immediately or retrospectively.

I just have a slight personal quibble with this due to the way my brain approaches games, as I often want to be aware of the entire picture, which isn’t possible here. This wouldn’t bother me in a competitive setting since I would mostly be focused on solving my own puzzle, but trying to solve a problem as a team when you’re not completely aware of what other players are capable of doing was difficult for me. It’s undoubtedly an effective way of eliminating the alpha gamer -problem from a game, but I would probably enjoy this the most solo.

Also in a more nitpicky sense, I think the production is kind of a mixed bag, the theme, the card artwork, and graphic design are top notch, but the board is very abstract, and the flimsy plastic pieces for the invaders feel like they’re components from a completely different game all-together, giving it quite the disjointed look. I get that people like it since “plastic = bad” but personally just was not a fan, though am definitely nitpicking here.
